answers.answer: I am sorry not to introduce myself before posting but I am freaking out a bit.  My name is Amy and I live in Michigan I have a long history of problems.  My story is as follows:  I have to break it up into two posts because it exceeds th 8000 character limit.I don't want to totally bore you but I have already written this out for my Doctor's appt. on Friday.A very short bio:I was born and Michigan in 1965.  In 1979 I moved to Maryland after the divorce of my parents.  In 1995 I moved back to Michigan to live closer to my sister.  I am 45 years old, married with two young children.I have always had a significant amount of stress in my life.  I grew up with a mother who suffered from mental illness and although not physically abused, I, along with my two siblings was verbally abused for many years.  This abuse still continues when I am in contact with her.  I was uprooted in my early teens to live with my father and the situation there was tense as well as he had started a new life with a new wife and child.  I did not attend college as I was eager to move out of my father's house and begin my own life.I was alone and happy for the next six years until I met and married my husband in 1991.  Our marriage has been extremely unhappy and stressful from the beginning.  We remain married and have two children ages 10 and 11.  My health has always taken a back seat and I come from a "pull yourself up by your bootstraps" family mentality so I dismissed a lot of things on factors I could control myself.It has been a long time since I have felt well and my memory is very poor.  I have kept adequate health records and will list all aches, pains, surgeries and illnesses as I remember them and have documentation for.My medical history:Smoker from 1980 - 2001Birth Control Pills from 1981 - 1991Fibrocystic Breast Disease - 1987 - PresentHashimoto's Thyroiditis - 1993 - PresentIn 1993 I was diagnosed with Hashimoto's Thyroiditis after two miscarriages.  Prior to that the only health issue I had was fibrocystic breasts.  I honestly don't know what actually came first and I had never heard of either.  I was put on thyroid medication but never quite felt the same again.  My main problems were muscle tightness and breast pain.In 1994 I had two bouts of blood in my urine.  Not just traces of blood but urinating blood.  There was never any infection found and no pain was involved.  I had scans of my kidneys and usual tests for infections and was told all was normal.  Both instances resolved on their own after about 10 days and have never returned.I became pregnant with my first child in March 1999.  I was sick from day one and was hospitalized four weeks prior to my due date with preeclampsia.  I weighed 115 lbs. when I became pregnant and was 200 lbs upon delivery.   I was induced three weeks early and delivery was normal vaginal delivery with epidural.As a new mother I was incredibly tired with a baby who never slept.  I still worked full time and had my verbally abusive mother watch my young baby while I was at work.   The fatigue and stress was enormous.

Amy's history continued:In 2000, history repeated itself again with another unplanned pregnancy.  The result of the pregnancy were the same with preeclampsia and a slightly premature infant.  I was sleeping on average two to three hours nightly, still working and dealing with my abusive mother and disappearing marriage.As I write this it sounds so depressing but I was never felt  depressed.  I always was and still am a very intrinsically happy person.  I was and am very tired due to lack of sleep but never irritable or depressed.I always managed to do what was necessary to keep myself and household under control and was always a happy mother.  I see depression in both my siblings and have been around mental illness all my life so I know about depression.  I have never felt depressed.  I love life and remain very happy in spite of all that I have been through.In 2004 I remember wanting to take control of feeling better.  I had gained so much weight and because I suffered from insomnia, I binged on sugar daily to keep awake.  I weighed 155 lbs. and believed all my problems were due to a thyroid imbalance but could never find a doctor to agree.  I was treated based on test results not on symptoms.Around this same time 2004-2005 I began to experience pain in both my feet.  It felt as if my shoes were too tight.  I know now this is neuropathy but at the time I didn't know what is was called.  I kept buying different shoes but nothing made it better.  I went to my PCP and he did a glucose test that turned out normal and then said he didn't know what it was and to use orthotics and lose weight.  This terrible burning tightness went on for three years.In the spring of 2005 I was driving down the road feeling fine when I had sudden acute bladder pain.  This pain has been the single most painful event of my life.  I was close to home and instead of driving to the emergency room, I went home to lay on the floor for two days of constant pain.  I found some old Darvacet in the cabinet and lived off that until I could stand upright long enough to seek help.  I began to have constant pain to the point of avoiding tampons and sexual intercourse because of the pain.  I began urinating every 20 minutes.  Although it was not painful to urinate, there was a constant pain.  I saw my Gynecologist who found no infection and referred me to a urologist.  The Urologist tested for infection and looked inside my bladder and found nothing.  I can't stress enough the significance of this in my life.  For the next five years, I was urinating between 40 - 70 times per day and about four times nightly.  The pain persisted but it was not as severe as the initial "attack".  Again, I sought answers to no avail.In July 2006 I was standing in ankle deep in a cold swimming pool and my big toe on my left foot kept pulling upward.  The sensation was uncomfortable so I stayed out of the water.  I now know this is a Babinski reflex but at the time I did not know what the reflex was.In 2007, I went on a benefit walk and noticed I was limping.  My legs felt stiff and I could not finish the three mile walk.  I put off seeking help for this until July of 2008 when my limp did not go away.  My PCP told me it was sciatica but sent me for an emg.  In July 2008 I was told I had a pinched nerve and needed physical therapy.  I could not afford physical therapy so I printed out some exercises I found on the Internet and did them with no resolution.  I developed Plantar Fasciitis in my left foot that I could not get rid of until 2009.  Very painful.In October of 2007, I took my kids trick-or-treating and barely made it home. (About one mile).  My walking was stiff and uncomfortable and I was still limping.Halloween 2008 - Same problem,  a little worse, but I did make it home.In the  late summer - early fall of 2008 I was living on no sleep because of insomnia, still eating poorly, battling frequent urination, limping and suffering with painful feet.  I then woke up one morning and noticed the left side of my face was drooping badly.  Mostly my mouth.  The first thing that came to my mind was a stroke.  I noticed my left arm was weak.  I wasn't sure if this had been ongoing and just pronounced on that day because I was so exhausted or an "event" that had occurred during the night.  I neglected the incident all together and went to work.  I noticed as the day went on my face was off but I felt okay.  From this point on, I noticed my typing speed was off on my left side.  I could still type two handed only slower than I had been.In January of 2009 I had my first leg spasm.  It was an extensor spasm in both my legs at the same time.  It would happen infrequently when I laid on my back only.  I also started to become aware of my cognitive decline.  I blamed this on insomnia too.  Simple math or spelling was a challenge and I constantly was forgetting simple tasks.  This continues to this day.In May 2009 I saw an Orthopedic Doctor who ordered x-rays of my spine.  He also ordered a MRI of my neck and lumbar spine.  He told me I had some cervical spine problems but not enough to cause my symptoms.  He told me my basically spine was fine and I should see a Neurologist.The next month, June 2009, I saw my first Neurologist who performed blood work and standard office test for reflexes, eye movements, etc.  He said all was normal and to see a Rheumatologist.  He said my Lupus test was normal and did not have an answer to my stiffness and limp.In July 2009, I went to a new Endocrinologist about lower leg pain I was having.  Blood tests revealed low vitamin D.  I was told my thyroid was normal.  I was put on vitamin D but pain did not go away.  My leg pain became increasingly worse and at this point I really new something was terribly wrong but I didn't know where to seek treatment.  I knew I was losing strength on my left side and also my ability to walk.  I also noticed I would wake up a couple of nights weekly with uncontrolled shivering or night sweats.  My body could not regulate my temperature.November 2009, I went to a Rheumatologist who was able to see I had neurological deficits.  He was able to elicit a Babinki sign on my left foot and said i had Hyperreflexia and Spasticity. He said to go back to the Neurologist for further evaluation.  When I asked him about my muscle pain he said I had Fibromyalgia and gave me a prescription of Flexeril.  I asked if it could be my thyroid and he said no.  I took a Flexeril and it made me very loopy so I never took one again.December 2009, I went back to the original Neurologist who ordered a MRI of my brain and a SSEP Test.  Both were normal.  He prescribed baclofen for my spasticity.

At this point I was getting weaker and could not hold much weight with my left hand.  My leg was dragging and my anxiety was increasing fast.  I started taking vitamins including a lot of vitamin B.  Almost immediately my frequent urination stopped.  After 5 years, I was back to normal urinary frequency.  I don't know if it was the vitamins or not but I am completely normal as far as my bladder goes.  ??In March of 2010, my mother recommended I go see a physiatrist.  I did.  He said I could have thoracic outlet syndrome and ordered a cervical and thoracic MRI.  At this time I began having widespread fasciculations.  When my MRI's were normal, I was convinced I had ALS.  The same doctor gave me an emg that was normal.  I was still concerned about ALS because I now had both upper and lower motor neuron signs and had lost most function in my left hand and arm along with foot drop.  I could see the muscle between my thumb and forefinger was atrophied and I had lots of visible fasciculations.The Physiatrist sent me to the U of M in Ann Arbor where I had lots of blood drawn.  I was unimpressed with the Doctor not giving me a complete neurological exam and looking at my left hand/leg.  At this time, I could not walk without tennis shoes on as I could gain no traction nor could I raise my left arm over my head.In July 2010, I gave up on the U of M and went to an ALS specialist at the Detroit Medical Center in Detroit.  He saw my motor deficits and agreed I may have ALS because I had no sensory symptoms and normal MRI's.  He scheduled an emg/nerve conduction that he attended and supervised.  The tests were normal and said I most likely had Primary Lateral Sclerosis because the emg did not detect lower motor neuron problems.  He referred me to the other ALS specialist at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit.In December 2010 I had another emg/nerve conduction done by the Henry Ford ALS director Dr. Newman.  This test was normal.  He said while looking over my MRI record, there was something seen on my brain stem MRI.  He ordered a spinal tap.In March 2011, I had a spinal tap.  The results of the spinal tap were four or more oligoclonal bands.  The ALS doctor called and he said I did not have ALS but most likely Primary Progressive MS.  He referred me to the Henry Ford MS specialist.The Henry Ford MS specialist ordered more MRI's of my brain and full spine.  She said I had Primary Progressive MS and told me there was no treatment.  She gave me a booklet about MS and said to come back in four months.After my series of MRI's, the Henry Ford MS secretary called to tell me that there is a lesion on my brain stem and C1 cervical spine but I did not meet the criteria for MS.  I assumed this was the McDonald criteria.  My MS diagnosis was revoked.  I was told to keep repeating MRI's every so often to look for more lesions.In May 2011, I went to my PCP to see what he thought and he said I had a lot of problems for having one lesion.  He told me I could go to Mayo Clinic but because I have  had pretty extensive testing already, he thought the expense of Mayo may just have the same outcome of possible MS.  I asked him about putting me on Low Dose Naltrexone for Inflammation, Hashimoto's....... He said he had not heard of it and would not prescribe it nor could I obtain a prescription for Natural Thyroid, Armour, etc.I went to the Internet because of Tendonitis and Plantar Fasciitis of now my right foot.  I read about eliminating gluten and learned about Lyme being common and often misdiagnosed.  I did eliminate gluten and had my blood drawn for Lyme.  I grew up in a wooded area and was always outside.  I was bitten by a few ticks as a child but never remember any rash.As of today, I can only walk a short distance unaided. I have lost most use of my left arm and hand, I have uninterrupted memory and cognitive problems, joint pain, muscle pain, leg pain due to spasticity, and foot pain. I also have moderate light sensitivity, cyclical fibrocystic breasts,  general weakness and overall malaise.I remain undiagnosed.My IGenex Results are:Lyme IGM Western Blot:Igenex - PositiveCDC/NYS - Negative18 kDa +**23-25 kDa -23 kDa -30 kDa -**31 kDa IND**34 kDa -**39 kDa IND**41 kDa ++45 kDa +58 kDa +66 kDa -**83-93 kDa ++Lyme IgG Western Blot:Igenex - NegativeCDC/Nys Result - Negative18 kDa -**23-25 kDa -23 kDa -30 kDa -**31 kDa IND**34 kDa -**39 kDa IND**41 kDa +45 kDa -58 kDa -66 kDa -**83-93 kDa -IFA, B Burgdoferi - Result 40Equivocal

Briefly,The starred (***) are the ones which most specifically refer to Lyme so those are important to look at.Igenex is a laboratory that runs the tests and gives its interpretaton, then it will also give the interpretation that the CDC (Centers for Disease Control) uses -- the CDC uses a higher standard, which Lyme docs believe ignores too many people who actually have Lyme.  (The CDC set its standards for epidemiological purposes long ago, trying to track absolute, certain, slamdunk cases of Lyme, but those very high standards have more recently been used by nonLyme specialists for diagnosis.  That means a lot of people truly ill with Lyme are excluded by CDC standards.)IgM results test for the antibodies your immune system makes shortly after infection; IgG antibodies are made after a period of time when the IgM reaction is fading.  There is no specific time cut off on which one fades and the other leaps up.The 'double starred' (**) bands are the ones most important to a Lyme diagnosis.If you go to truthaboutlymedisease [dot] com, there is a post from 2009 that lays out what each band means.On your IgM results, on the double-starred bands:**23-25 kDa -**31 kDa IND   ===>  "IND" means 'indeterminate' meaning 'maybe', but this is an important one, because if you have this, only Lyme would make this band light up (it is 'specific' to Lyme)**34 kDa -**39 kDa IND   ===> this is also specific to Lyme**41 kDa ++    ===>  could be Lyme, could be something else**83-93 kDa ++  ===> also specific to LymeHOWEVER  what is important to remember is that the tests are very imperfect, and they are used only to ASSIST in diagnosis, not to MAKE the diagnosis.  Like a pregnancy test:  it may be negative, but if your stomach gets big and you're getting kicked from the inside, you're pretty surely pregnant no matter what the test says.Let us know how you do after you see your doc --

Sorry, I missed most of your post the first time through  (I think you were still posting while I was answering your first post).You are clearly a strong and motivated person, and I admire you for your strength in all you have been (and still are) going through.You are right about Lyme being overlooked and misdiagnosed.  No one here at this website is medically trained that I know of, so all we can do is give you ideas of where to look for help.Finding an LLMD is my most significant suggestion.  That's not an official title, and docs don't use it themselves, but it helps us the patients designate a doc who thinks bigger thoughts about Lyme than mainstream medicine does.  I don't see that you say where you live now (what state, what cities you are near) (or you did and I missed it in your post), but there are ways to find LLMDs online.  If you post back here what state/cities you are near, we'll give you some ideas.MS is a common misdiagnosis for Lyme.  Neurologists, rheumatologists and infectious disease docs are well known for not understanding or taking Lyme into account, so again your situation is sadly not all that uncommon.  There is a group for LLMDs, ILADS [dot] org, and there you will find under the tab 'about Lyme' a post by Dr Burrascano called "Diagnostic Hints ...".  It's written in a conversational fashion for medical people, but is very readable if you are up for it.A caution:  There are docs who treat Lyme and consider themselves specialists, but because Lyme is on the frontiers of medicine, there are some wacky things and treatments that even MDs will prescribe.  Keep your skeptical hat on when finding a doc --Best wishes --

I am sincerely sorry that you are going through this.  I think a lot of people on here, including me, can understand the anxiety of falling apart physically and feeling like there is no one that can help or even just give it a simple name.   It is a terrible feeling.  I wish you the best as you move forward with all this.  Ness

dear amy,i am as-of-yet undiagnosed, and an infrequent contributor here, but was compelled to respond to your post.  i am so, so sorry to know you are suffering so, and my heart goes out to you.i'm curious to know who ordered your igenex tests.  if it wasn't a lyme literate doc, listen to jackie and get in to see a reputable LLMD as soon as possible.  (just FYI--in my opinion, you should listen to jackie in just about every respect.  she is super knowledgeable about the ins and outs of this craziness.)i am also curious as to whether you have had your vitamin B12 levels checked during the many visits to the different docs.  you noticed some improvement when you took B vitamins which is interesting to me.my thoughts are with you and i'll look forward to hearing about your progress.blessings to you as you embark on this journey,binx

Thank you for the replies - I don't know what to think.  It seems some people get better and some people don't and I don't understand this.I spent 4 months reading about ALS and 4 months reading about MS and I am sooo tired of reading about things that don't pertain to my situation.I will see a LLMD tomorrow and go from there.  I absolutely HATE doctors so I am going half-hearted with my obscenely thick medical file in hopes for answers.From what I have read on the Internet, my results show something and people have been treated based on less bands showing positive - and let's not forget the fact I look a mess.Usually I am very upbeat but today I have PMS so I am crabby.  I get so tired of seeing what are supposed to be the best years of my life wasting away.I am still grateful to be alive though.  Sigh.............BTW, Happy 4th!

Thanks Binx,I know my bio reads like a horror show but it is what I am taking to a reputable LLMD in Michigan.  I had my PCP's office draw my blood so I could have the results to take to a LLMD.I have been tested for Vitamin B as I thought the same thing but my levels are normal.  I have given approximately 70 vials of blood over the past year to test for various things. ?????We should be on that show Mystery Diagnosis!
I am also very sorry to hear about your situation and can relate. Let us know what the LLMD says, OK?

Saw the LLMD yesterday and he matter-of-factly stated he was confident all my problems were from Lyme and put me on 300 mg doxy. daily, LDN, and Armour thyroid.I am cautiously optimistic.  This Doctor seems to think everything is caused by Lyme and I do not.  Also I don't warm up to doctors too easily and he is no different.I left his office with my doxy prescription and that's all I was hoping for so the visit was a success.Thank you for listening and sharing.  I still can't believe we live in this nightmare.
Hang in there -- I hope you see improvement soon.  Keep us posted --

question: I am trying to pack for a weeks vacation for me and my kids and I am super pressed for time. Of course my results came in from IGenex today and I don't have enough time to study all of this.Can you please tell me (If you know) what this means?Lyme IGM Western Blot:Igenex - PositiveCDC/NYS - Negative18 kDa +**23-25 kDa -23 kDa -30 kDa -**31 kDa IND**34 kDa -**39 kDa IND**41 kDa ++45 kDa +58 kDa +66 kDa -**83-93 kDa ++Lyme IgG Western Blot:Igenex - NegativeCDC/Nys Result - Negative18 kDa -**23-25 kDa -23 kDa -30 kDa -**31 kDa IND**34 kDa -**39 kDa IND**41 kDa +45 kDa -58 kDa -66 kDa -**83-93 kDa -IFA, B Burgdoferi - Result 40EquivocalPlease help if you can. This will drive me crazy if I have to go away without knowing what this means.Bless you all!
title: IGenex Results - Long time neuro problems
